awd_titl_txt: Effects of Mechanically-Induced Stress on the Proteome and Development
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant will support work to better understand how the physical environment influences biology.  Specifically, this grant will support work to better understand how proteins respond to mechanical forces.  Organisms are continuously sensing mechanical forces and respond appropriately.  For example, the Earth’s gravity is constantly pulling down and the atmospheric pressure which compresses from all directions, yet organisms can remain upright. If the ability to sense these physical effects is compromised, it can lead to developmental disorders, muscle and bone loss, neurological abnormalities, immunological, and age-related problems.  These conditions have been observed even in astronauts, who are exposed to microgravity during prolonged times away from Earth.  The work done under this grant use novel microtechnology systems that mimic different physical environments.  These microtechnology systems will be used to investigate how mechanical changes in the physical environment differentially affect thousands of proteins.  Characterizing these biological responses will ultimately lead to improvements in national health. For example, the results of this work may ultimately inform future therapeutic strategies or disease prevention techniques. This project will also create an educational and training program for interdisciplinary collaboration.  Engineers and biological scientists will work together, and participation in research for underrepresented groups will be broadened. 

Different types of Earth’s physical forces continuously impact living beings as a part of their ceaseless adaptation to external stimuli. While much is known about mechanotransduction in specific sensory systems, little is known about generalized mechanosensation of the surrounding physical environment by whole organisms. One reason for this lack of knowledge is the limited methods to mechanically stimulate enough whole organisms to enable comprehensive proteomic analysis. To investigate generalized mechanosensation, hundreds of living Drosophila embryos will be exposed to multiple modes, amplitudes, and durations of various mechanical stimulation such as microgravity, hypergravity, and external compression using microfabricated high-throughput devices that will be developed. This work will utilize the comparative proteomics approach of 2D-DIGE (2 Dimensional Difference Gel Electrophoresis) to identify changes in protein abundance or post-translational regulation in response to these different modes of mechanical stimulation. This approach will also enable the proteomic comparison of local/acute to chronic/ubiquitous mechanical stimulation. By using comparative proteomics in conjunction with the analysis of developmental phenotypes, the extent to which these mechanical modes are specialized, or overlap in a universal pathway of mechanotransduction in the context of whole organisms will be examined.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The research for this project came at an important time as engineering is driving toward future products and medically useful approaches in the United States. The responses of multicellular biology systems are very related to engineering for developing future therapies and diagnostics. While traditional approaches are making some progress, addressing these challenges with logical yet novel ideas may lead to significant insights for biological approaches and responses in the future. One goal of this project was that life exists in a mechanical context. Mechanical stimulation is converted into biological signals through complex and diverse pathways. When these fail, they result in numerous pathologies including developmental disorders, muscle and bone loss, neurological responses, and age-related disorders. While there are many mechanical stresses in animals, two of the most important modes are chronic and acute. We developed experimental systems for addressing these two modes of mechanical stress, which allowed us to begin to uncover the intricacies of how different mechanical environments affects organisms. We developed devices to increase and decrease chronic gravitational load and high-throughput devices to impose acute, localized mechanical forces on organisms. We also screened for mechanically induced proteomic changes. These pathways helped inform how we understand and treat mechanical components of cell function, development, and pathology. This team was uniquely qualified for this project by virtue of its diverse strengths in multi-cellular systems, microfluidics, and cell and molecular biology. Furthermore, by providing fundamental understanding, this research targeted the successful implementation of these ideas in academia, government, and industry.

 

The intellectual merit was to discover unknown proteomic responses to several modes of mechanical stimulation, including chronic hypergravity and microgravity, and acute compression. Chronic and acute mechanical stresses have been shown to affect many biological processes, such as heart function, neural response, and the immune system. We developed novel devices to apply acute and chronic mechanical stimulation in order identify which proteins and mechanical transduction pathways are involved in sensing and transducing mechanical force. The proteins that respond to the mechanical forces are unknown, so we looked at all proteins in an organism to find which ones change by abundance or post-translational modification in response to mechanical stimulation. Together, these approaches led us to a better understanding of biological responses to mechanical stimulation. The proposed interdisciplinary research combined complementary skill sets and research infrastructure of the research groups with expertise in microfluidics, cell biology, and imaging.

 

The broader impact of these studies included building an education and training pipeline for preparing future leaders in engineering and science. This was accomplished through work with K-12 students, undergraduate students, and graduate students. One major focus was to develop a successful underrepresented PhD program building off of successes for underrepresented PhD individual students. These efforts also included work with academically challenged public schools in Pennsylvania. In addition, work was extended through the Proteomics Platoon bringing meaningful research experiences to undergraduates.

 

The results from the research over this grant have been presented in more than 15 peer-reviewed archival journal publications, 40 presentations, and have provided support for 2 PhD students. The work has been presented at a variety of conferences including the Biomedical Engineering Society, the Biophysical Society, and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. Graduate students involved in this project developed a combined biology and engineering background that have made them highly valuable in industry and academics.  In addition, the research of this project was fundamental, yet required an intuitive, hands-on understanding of mechanical engineering merged with biology.  This combination of skills provided them a unique training for a graduate-level project. Students in this program also benefited greatly from interactions with other engineering and biology faculty. The graduation of these students helped address the growing industry and scientific need for multidisciplinary engineers and scientists, who are comfortable working in teams of diverse technical background.


Last Modified: 06/20/2024
Modified by: Philip R Leduc

  • Measuring the fluid profile enabled by our solenoid based approach. Schematic of the microfluidic setup. The solenoid valve is operated by an Arduino and controls the flow of the red-dyed water.
    DeAngelis, M., Ruder, W.*, LeDuc, P.* An embedded microfluidic valve for dynamic control of cellular communication. Applied Physics Letters 123: 244103, (2023).
    Copyrighted
    Philip R Leduc
    Novel microfluidic based approach for stimulating multi-cellular systems.
  • Novel microfabrication techniques enabled the production of different microfluidic tools which, in turn, facilitated the development of experimental paradigms for small multicellular models
    Frey, N., Sonmez, U., Minden, J.S.*, LeDuc, P.R.* Microtechnologies for Understanding and Engineering Model Biological Organisms. Nature Communications 13: 3195, DOI: 10.1038/s41467-022-30814-6 (2022).
    Copyrighted
    Philip R Leduc
    Transdisciplinary directions for biological model organism research enabled by novel microfluidic approaches.
